G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in the Somerville District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19, as this matter involves a claim for damages not exceeding $50,000 arising under Massachusetts landlord-tenant law.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord who “directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant” is liable for damages or other relief.

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects tenants from “serious interference with their tenancy.” *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 716–718 (1977).
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the scope of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and treats substantial interference with the tenant’s use of the premises (here, severe late-night noise) as a breach. The court affirms that a landlord’s conduct that results in conditions making the premises not reasonably habitable—amounting to a very substantial deprivation of quiet enjoyment—violates the covenant, thereby recognizing protection against serious interference with tenancy.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found that the tenants were ‘very substantially deprived’ of quiet enjoyment of their leased premises ‘for a substantial time’… He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Other Massachusetts courts have similarly held landlords responsible for failing to abate disturbances by other tenants: *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982); *Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982); *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997); *Brown v. LeClair*, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976 (1985); *Hemingway v. Lanier*, 174 Mass. 589 (1899); *Lipschitz v. Plunkett*, 175 Mass. 55 (1900); *Jablonski v. Clemons*, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 473 (2004); *Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184 (1973); *Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987).
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The proposition is about landlord responsibility for failing to abate disturbances by *other tenants*. Simon v. Solomon concerns flooding and unsanitary physical conditions in the plaintiff’s own apartment, allegedly caused by building conditions and plumbing backups, with the landlord’s liability grounded in warranty of habitability, quiet enjoyment, and emotional distress. Although the opinion briefly notes that other tenants may have caused backups by misuse of plumbing, the holding is not about noise, harassment, or other tenant disturbances or the landlord’s duty to control them; it is about failure to maintain habitable, watertight premises. Thus it does not meaningfully support the specific proposition stated.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “Gem also gave evidence concerning the structure of Solomon’s building and the possible cause of flooding, and argued that third persons were responsible for any floods that occurred. … The water in Solomon’s apartment was a preventable situation, and one that Gem had a duty to prevent. See 105 Code Mass. Regs. 410.500; Crowell v. McCaffrey, 377 Mass. 443 (1979); Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973).”

*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Other Massachusetts courts have similarly held landlords responsible for failing to abate disturbances by other tenants: *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982); *Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982); *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997); *Brown v. LeClair*, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976 (1985); *Hemingway v. Lanier*, 174 Mass. 589 (1899); *Lipschitz v. Plunkett*, 175 Mass. 55 (1900); *Jablonski v. Clemons*, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 473 (2004); *Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184 (1973); *Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987).
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The proposition is about landlords’ responsibility for failing to abate disturbances caused by other tenants. Lowery v. Robinson concerns a landlord’s failure to provide heat and resulting liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 for breach of quiet enjoyment, not disturbances or misconduct by other tenants. While it reinforces strict landlord liability for interference with quiet enjoyment, it does not address or impose liability for failure to abate disturbances by other tenants, so it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season … seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. … It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’ … Thus … liability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.proposition: Other Massachusetts courts have similarly held landlords responsible for failing to abate disturbances by other tenants: *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982); *Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982); *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997); *Brown v. LeClair*, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976 (1985); *Hemingway v. Lanier*, 174 Mass. 589 (1899); *Lipschitz v. Plunkett*, 175 Mass. 55 (1900); *Jablonski v. Clemons*, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 473 (2004); *Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184 (1973); *Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987).
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.support_reasoning: The proposition is that Massachusetts courts have held landlords responsible for failing to abate disturbances by other tenants. Al‑Ziab v. Mourgis concerns lead paint poisoning and whether a statutory lead paint violation, without fault, constitutes a breach of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment. It does not involve disturbances caused by other tenants, nor landlord responsibility for failing to control or abate those disturbances, so it does not support the specific proposition cited.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment)… Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence.”

*Brown v. LeClair*, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 97.proposition: Other Massachusetts courts have similarly held landlords responsible for failing to abate disturbances by other tenants: *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982); *Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982); *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997); *Brown v. LeClair*, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976 (1985); *Hemingway v. Lanier*, 174 Mass. 589 (1899); *Lipschitz v. Plunkett*, 175 Mass. 55 (1900); *Jablonski v. Clemons*, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 473 (2004); *Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184 (1973); *Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987).
*Brown v. LeClair*, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 97.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns landlord responsibility for failing to abate disturbances caused by other tenants. Brown v. LeClair deals with a landlord’s liability for physical defects and code violations in the premises (leaks, roaches, inadequate front door) and related G.L. c. 93A damages, not with disturbances or misconduct by other tenants. The only assault discussed is by a neighbor who broke through a flimsy door; the landlord’s liability is tied to the defective door, not to any failure to control or abate the neighbor’s conduct as a tenant disturbance.
*Brown v. LeClair*, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 97.relevant_excerpt: “These damages were based on a September, 1980, incident in which LeClair was assaulted with a knife by a neighbor after the neighbor punched a hole through LeClair’s hollow core front door and entered his apartment. The judge found that the construction of the door to LeClair’s apartment did not provide adequate security and was in violation of the State Sanitary Code… There was evidence that the door was of flimsy construction.”

*Hemingway v. Lanier*, 174 Mass. 589 (18.proposition: Other Massachusetts courts have similarly held landlords responsible for failing to abate disturbances by other tenants: *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982); *Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982); *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997); *Brown v. LeClair*, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976 (1985); *Hemingway v. Lanier*, 174 Mass. 589 (1899); *Lipschitz v. Plunkett*, 175 Mass. 55 (1900); *Jablonski v. Clemons*, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 473 (2004); *Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184 (1973); *Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987).
*Hemingway v. Lanier*, 174 Mass. 589 (18.support_reasoning: This case is a defamation/slander decision about allegedly slanderous statements made in a church setting; it does not concern landlord‑tenant law, disturbances by other tenants, or any duty of a landlord to abate such disturbances. The opinion never addresses landlord obligations, quiet enjoyment, or tenant harassment, so citing it for the proposition that Massachusetts courts hold landlords responsible for failing to abate disturbances by other tenants is inaccurate.
*Hemingway v. Lanier*, 174 Mass. 589 (18.relevant_excerpt: There was no such relation between the defendant and the other members of the choir as to make it his duty to inform them what he knew or had heard in regard to the character of the plaintiff. The members of the choir were employees of the church under a contract to assist at its services. They had no duty to perform or interest to serve which made it necessary or proper to inform them that the plaintiff had been guilty of adultery.

*Lipschitz v. Plunkett*, 175 Mass. 55 (1.proposition: Other Massachusetts courts have similarly held landlords responsible for failing to abate disturbances by other tenants: *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982); *Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982); *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997); *Brown v. LeClair*, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976 (1985); *Hemingway v. Lanier*, 174 Mass. 589 (1899); *Lipschitz v. Plunkett*, 175 Mass. 55 (1900); *Jablonski v. Clemons*, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 473 (2004); *Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184 (1973); *Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987).
*Lipschitz v. Plunkett*, 175 Mass. 55 (1.case_name: Blanchette v. Holyoke Street Railway Co.
*Lipschitz v. Plunkett*, 175 Mass. 55 (1.support_reasoning: This case is a street railway personal injury/negligence case involving a collision between two electric cars and the conductor’s negligence. It does not involve a landlord-tenant relationship, disturbances by other tenants, or any duty of a landlord to abate such disturbances. Citing Lipschitz v. Plunkett for the proposition that Massachusetts courts hold landlords responsible for failing to abate disturbances by other tenants is therefore inaccurate.
*Lipschitz v. Plunkett*, 175 Mass. 55 (1.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff was a passenger on an open electric car of the defendant company… there was evidence which would warrant a finding that she was thrown from the car by reason of its coming into collision with the rear end of another car of the defendant… We are of opinion that on the facts of the case there was evidence to warrant a finding of negligence on the part of the conductor.”

*Jablonski v. Clemons*, 60 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Other Massachusetts courts have similarly held landlords responsible for failing to abate disturbances by other tenants: *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982); *Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982); *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997); *Brown v. LeClair*, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976 (1985); *Hemingway v. Lanier*, 174 Mass. 589 (1899); *Lipschitz v. Plunkett*, 175 Mass. 55 (1900); *Jablonski v. Clemons*, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 473 (2004); *Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184 (1973); *Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987).
*Jablonski v. Clemons*, 60 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The proposition claims that other Massachusetts courts have held landlords responsible for failing to abate disturbances by other tenants. In Jablonski, the court held the landlord liable for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment where moisture, odors, and ventilation problems originating from other units were known and uncorrected for nine years, constituting a serious interference with the tenancy. This fits squarely within the line of cases imposing liability on landlords for failing to address tenant-generated or building-wide conditions that substantially impair another tenant’s use and enjoyment.
*Jablonski v. Clemons*, 60 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: Here, the judge found that the landlord knowingly rented the premises in a defective condition and failed to correct the ventilation problem — a serious code violation — for over nine years. Because of the defective ventilation, the tenants were forced to keep the bathroom door shut and to run the fan continuously, a dangerous situation which led to a fire in the apartment. The moisture and foul odor problems originating in other units, the judge found, were never eliminated and persisted to the time of trial. On these facts found by the judge, we think that the judge was required to find a serious interference with the tenancy and substantial impairment of the character and value of the leased premises.

*Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363.proposition: Other Massachusetts courts have similarly held landlords responsible for failing to abate disturbances by other tenants: *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982); *Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982); *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997); *Brown v. LeClair*, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976 (1985); *Hemingway v. Lanier*, 174 Mass. 589 (1899); *Lipschitz v. Plunkett*, 175 Mass. 55 (1900); *Jablonski v. Clemons*, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 473 (2004); *Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184 (1973); *Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987).
*Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns landlord liability for failing to abate disturbances by other tenants. This Hemingway opinion (a concurrence/dissent) deals with implied warranty of habitability, the effect of State Sanitary Code violations, and interdependence of rent and repair obligations. It does not address landlord duties regarding disturbances or misconduct by other tenants, nor any duty to control such third-party behavior, so it does not support the stated proposition.
*Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363.relevant_excerpt: “The tenants defend principally on the following grounds… that the Housing Inspection Department had inspected defendant’s apartment… and found said apartment to be in violation of the State Sanitary Code… and that said violations and conditions… render the apartment uninhabitable… The opinion of the court holds that the tenants are subject to eviction because of their failure to pay rent, but that their liability for unpaid rent is limited to the reasonable value, if any, of their apartments, considering the alleged violations of the Code.”

*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Other Massachusetts courts have similarly held landlords responsible for failing to abate disturbances by other tenants: *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982); *Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982); *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997); *Brown v. LeClair*, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976 (1985); *Hemingway v. Lanier*, 174 Mass. 589 (1899); *Lipschitz v. Plunkett*, 175 Mass. 55 (1900); *Jablonski v. Clemons*, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 473 (2004); *Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184 (1973); *Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987).
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The proposition concerns landlord responsibility for failing to abate disturbances by other tenants. This opinion does not address tenant-on-tenant disturbances, nuisance, quiet enjoyment, or any duty of the landlord to control other tenants’ behavior. Instead, it deals with security deposits, utilities, rent control overcharges, warranty of habitability regarding code violations, and Chapter 93A applicability. Therefore, it does not support the specific proposition for which it is cited.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt:
The violations include the existence of lead paint, cracked windows, missing window screens, stained ceiling, loose bathroom tiles, mice, ants, missing balustrades on the porches, inadequate trash receptables, and inadequate door locks.

Patukonis challenges the judge’s award of $625 in damages for the breach of warranty of habitability, maintaining that the judge failed both to use the "percentage reduction approach" in calculating damages and to make specific findings regarding the extent of each violation.
